I can't argue against that. Well put.

If only it were named better. I'm not sure what a "session facade" has to do with a "session". I call it "Business Logic Gateway". I can't remember what Martin Fowler calls it in his book.

Thanks.

So said Mike Clark on 4/4/2003 --------------------
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>I will make a statement that probably better belongs on another list, but I'll make it here and welcome either private responses or an invitation to a more appropriate place to discuss this.
>
>I do not react well to calling J2EE implementation idioms "patterns". They are hacks designed to increase performance and work around the obvious limitations and faulty intentions of J2EE.
>
>Session facade is not a "pattern" in the sense of "improves design". It is a hack that gets around the fact that J2EE tries to hide RMI from the programmer. If we didn't have to worry about remote objects, then how would we design it? I don't think we'd arrive at these implementation idioms/hacks if it weren't for working around either remote objects or a persistence mechanism that tries to call "save" for every method call.
>  
>

IMO, it's a pattern in the sense that it is a common solution to a 
reoccurring problem in distributed computing.  By naming it, we 
establish a common vocabulary for recognizing and debating the problem. 
Moreover, I believe session facade does improve design.  It decouples 
remote clients from persistent objects, perhaps modeled as entity beans, 
and encapsulates business logic in a cohesive location.  That is, it's a 
layering technique to separate concerns and manage dependencies.  

One person's pattern is another person's hack.

Mike
